Comment: Well, basic as ever, a simple e4.
!? This is a pretty weird move I played, yeah, but if played well enough, you can win with this. This commences the Scandinavian (or center counter) Defence!
There was no other OK move here except for Nc3 and e5, and that's not even that good.

Of course, the queen takes back, but I found 3.c4 a quite controversial move. It does bring another way out for the queen, but it doesn't exactly provide much control on the center. Also, if I keep my grip on the pawn and the Bishop moves away, I get a free pawn! 3. Nc3 would probably have been better.

Of course, the queen takes back, but I found 3.c4 a quite controversial move. It does bring another way out for the queen, but it doesn't exactly provide much control on the center. Also, if I keep my grip on the pawn and the Bishop moves away, I get a free pawn! 3. Nc3 would probably have been better.

Other than Qe2, my opponent loses a pawn, (or rook, depending on how this is played.) If he blocks with 4. Be2, than I can simple use 4... Qxg2, forcing the bishop to come to f3. If he blocks 4. Ne2, than his c-pawn loses protection, and he loses a pawn. There are also setbacks with a less orginized position, and it ends in my move after 4... Qxe2 and 5. Bxe2 or Nxe2.
As described before, the only proper move here.
As described before, the only proper move here.
With this, he blocks me from taking his rook, and technically forcing my Queen back to g6. (with g5, he can use d4, putting my Queen on a further run and developing his pieces faster.
Alright, he brings his knight out. He could do Be4 now, threatening my queen.
Alright, he brings his knight out. He could do Be4 now, threatening my queen.
...But I don't let him. Let's see what he has to offer.
Now I'm trying to trade off my bad bishop for his good bishop!
Now I'm trying to trade off my bad bishop for his good bishop!
... He is still one pawn down.
... He is still one pawn down.
I don't know why, but I don't like this move. I think 9. Nd5 or Nb5 would have been better, as it threatens a Rook King fork.
Knight Block! Though this may seem worse than 9... Nd7 or even 9... c6, this is arguable better, because it actually allows Queen-side Castling without any consequences (O-O-O, Qxa7)
I guess that this is for development. What else? Oh yeah, it protects the D-pawn.
I castle, as planned. Now, there are two attackers attacking the d-pawn. I just need to bring my a-pawn to safety, now.
Knight and a pawn for a rook and a knight (or checkmate)! Fair trade, right?
Knight and a pawn for a rook and a knight (or checkmate)! Fair trade, right?
I guess he didn't think it was that good for him.
Let's see what he does. Hopefully he will take the knight. If not, then he still will lose some. (Yes, I notice the rook fork, just don't care)
Gasp! Rook Fork! Don't care! Not like I need that h rook anyways.
Too greedy. Technically costed him the game.
Too greedy. Technically costed him the game.
